Netflix‚Äôs Tour de France Unchained review: An entertaining recap with a Pogaƒçar-shaped hole

The Tour de France: Unchained docuseries covering the 2022 race has dropped on Netflix. Made by the same producers as F1‚Äôs popular Drive to Survive, the eight episodes follow the stories on the way to Jonas Vingegaard‚Äôs eventual victory in the fight for the maillot jaune, with a wider look at the teams and personalities in the peloton.

It‚Äôs something I would watch again, and each of the 45-minute episodes were crafted with stunning visuals and personal revelations. Anything that has the potential to get new fans into the sport is welcomed by me and it looks like a second season could be on the way at the 2023 Tour de France too.

Of course, spoiler alerts ahead for this review.

Who are the key players?

The first episode begins with an introduction to the ‚ÄòWolfpack‚Äô, or the Soudal-QuickStep team, one of eight teams featured in the docuseries. Understandably they cover Fabio Jakobsen‚Äôs background, from his horror crash at the Tour of Poland (repeated throughout the series a few more times than maybe necessary, given that so-called ‚Äòcrash porn‚Äô has faced criticism in recent years) and his role as a sprinter within the team.

Jumbo-Visma and EF Education-EasyPost are also shown in the first episode, albeit missing Magnus Cort‚Äôs impressive run in the King of the Mountains jersey, before AG2R-Citro√´n, Alpecin-Deceuninck, Groupama-FDJ,¬†Ineos Grenadiers and Bora-Hansgrohe are introduced in subsequent episodes. While covering eight out of 22 teams is a decent size sample, it might have been beneficial to cut this number down. I understand the French connection with AG2R-Citroen, but we still get this angle with fellow French outfit Groupama-FDJ.

However, with more teams come more opportunities to display the more human side of being a professional cyclist. Viewers were treated to camera crews at home with riders such as Wout van Aert (Jumbo-Visma) and his family, at the farm of Thibaut Pinot (Groupama-FDJ), and we learned why Jasper Philipsen (Alpecin-Deceuninck) has the ‚ÄòJasper Disaster‚Äô nickname. Covering so many teams means narratives naturally jump back and forth, which is easier to follow for more knowledgeable watchers aware of the outcome of the race than for newcomers, but still digestible enough.

The lack of Tadej Pogaƒçar and his UAE Team Emirates was not a surprise, but the docuseries not covering a key rival of the eventual winner left others having to fill in the gaps of his story. It would have been ideal to secure his participation, though this is not the fault of those filming the docuseries ‚Äì you can‚Äôt force Pogaƒçar to sit down when his team did not make the decision to be included. One thing that was a surprise, however, was the omission of arguably the key shot of the entire 2022 Tour de France.

An incredible act of sportsmanship

After @TamauPogi crashes on the final descent of Stage 18, Jonas Vingegaard waits for his rival to catch up and the duo exchange a handshake before the final summit finish of the 2022 Tour de France

#TDF2022 pic.twitter.com/11LH1zWBi0

‚Äî Velon CC (@VelonCC) July 21, 2022

It was the handshake felt around the world. All right, I‚Äôm being dramatic now, but this sign of sportsmanship between the Tour‚Äôs two leading protagonists sparked articles and coverage galore at the time. It was a handshake that signalled a temporary ceasefire between the two rivals, who were pushing each other to the limit and then some, with Vingegaard unclipping and almost coming off his bike and Pogaƒçar hitting the ground on the fast-paced Stage 18 descent of the Col de Spandelles towards the Hautacam. To exclude this was certainly an‚Ä¶ interesting choice.

How ‚Äòbehind-the-scenes‚Äô is it?

Crews were given access before, during and after stages through a mix of rider interviews to the camera and in-car videos, the latter comparable to the Orica-GreenEdge Backstage Pass brilliance from Dan Jones, and it‚Äôs refreshing to see riders sit down and tell their own story in their own words.

Our highlight of #TDFUnchained so far. Truth hurts G #whippersnappers pic.twitter.com/q7N2kBuQpb

‚Äî Watts Occurring (@Watts_Occurring) June 8, 2023

There‚Äôs also access to team hotels throughout the race, which provides us an insight into massage table talks on tactics or debriefs and a loving message from Sar, Geraint Thomas‚Äô wife, as a reminder on his age. Just in case he forgot.

You‚Äôre also able to see preparations in the build-up to the race. At one point, Alpecin-Deceuninck‚Äôs Mathieu van der Poel is on the floor retching from his efforts (no-one said pro cycling was glamorous) and Thibaut Pinot feeds a bottle to one of his baby goats before brushing his donkeys on his farm in M√©lisey. He delivers emotional quotes, such as ‚Äòsometimes I feel like I‚Äôm more popular than I am talented. There are days when I wish I got less love and more wins.‚Äô

What‚Äôs the verdict?

The moment we‚Äôve all been waiting for‚Ä¶ Tour de France: Unchained is now streaming on @netflix!

We‚Äôre almost as excited as Rigo and Magnus for the premiere. Get ready to relive the ‚Äò22 Tour de France with us.

Tour de France: Unchained is a decent watch that provides detailed insights into aspects of cycling without being either too jargon-laden for new viewers, or too watered down for established fans. Perhaps they should‚Äôve gone all-in for one or another, while framing the leading standings at the start and finish of the episodes could‚Äôve helped the narrative, as could the inclusion of Tadej Pogaƒçar and The Handshake. As a counterpoint, Drive to Survive managed without Max Verstappen for the fourth season, and in fairness the producers of Unchained have done a decent job of working around the lack of participation of one of the race‚Äôs key players.

There‚Äôs no doubt that Soudal-QuickStep‚Äôs Yves Lampaert‚Äôs quote from episode one, which sees him win the opening stage time-trial and wears the first yellow jersey of the race, is an all-timer in drawing viewers straight into how emotional cycling can be: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm just a farmer‚Äôs son from Belgium.‚Äô

The docuseries goes more in-depth than TV coverage at the time, and can provide a good day-or-so of watching. I really hope we gain some new fans of the sport with this. It‚Äôs glitzy enough to grab attention episode to episode if you‚Äôre not too invested but doesn‚Äôt stray too far from its overall narrative.

All in all, Netflix‚Äôs Tour de France: Unchained comes down to a level of personal preference. If you want documentaries with more detailed analysis, you can find them elsewhere, such as team-made documentaries. But if you want to watch a binge-able recap of the 2022 Tour de France in the run-up to the 2023 edition, no matter how much you know about cycling or remember about the race, this docuseries does a good job. Plus, it has Orla Chennaoui in, so that‚Äôs an added bonus for me.
